description: Small, round, and perpetually soot-stained. Talks too fast, forgets what he’s saying halfway through, and somehow manages to blow something up at least once a day. Claims every explosion is “a feature, not a bug.” Travels with a mechanical pigeon named Percival who’s _probably_ smarter than he is.

clichés.name: Inventor
tools_of_the_trade: A multi-pocketed lab coat full of unidentifiable gadgets
Goggles with multiple flip-down lenses (most cracked, some tinted weirdly)
A collapsible workbench that unfolds from a suitcase
Percival, the mechanical pigeon — doubles as a recorder, scout, and sometimes a flamethrower
likely_abilities: Design and build improbable contraptions on the fly
Reverse-engineer or jury-rig devices from scraps
Recognize and exploit weaknesses in mechanisms

clichés.name: Absent-Minded Professor
tools_of_the_trade: A stack of half-filled notebooks with no consistent numbering
Ink-stained fingers and a perpetually misplaced pen
A head full of brilliant, half-remembered theories
likely_abilities: Spout obscure scientific trivia or academic jargon at will
Forget key details in hilarious or inconvenient ways

clichés.name: Tinkering Gadgeteer
tools_of_the_trade: Tiny screwdriver set and magnifying monocle
Percival’s toolkit hidden in his chest compartment
likely_abilities: Repair or upgrade any mechanical device (with varying success)
Create quick mechanical distractions or traps
Fine-tune or sabotage clockwork, steampunk, or magitech mechanisms

clichés.name: Tea Enthusiast
tools_of_the_trade: A dented silver teapot with scorch marks
Ceramic cup that says “World’s 3rd Best Genius”
likely_abilities: Brew restorative or mood-improving tea under any conditions
Impress or distract with perfect tea ceremony etiquette
Use tea as an impromptu solvent, polish, or cooling agent

memories: Ah, yes — the time I accidentally turned the dean’s wig into a small weather system; quite the learning experience in localized barometric pressure!
Percival once outscored me on an intelligence test I built — though, in my defense, I hadn’t finished calibrating the sarcasm sensors.
